moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5
comment: Very suspicious looking at first sight, but black will not necessarily castle kingside, and he hopes to control the dark-squares and keep the initiative. The f8-bishop is prepared to fianchetto without losing time.  By the way, these are just my observations and, be as they may, the opening has gone respectable in the last few years.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. Be2 h5 11. Bxg4
comment: Instead of trying to detonate the position, white has found an efficient way to deploy his pieces based on challenging the a1-h8 diagonal with a gain of time.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. Be2 h5 11. Bxg4 Bxg4
comment: Remember that in last week's game black played 11...hxg4.  The bishop recapture certainly appears more natural, however, and I think that you have to know this game to understand why someone would take with the pawn.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. Be2 h5 11. Bxg4 Bxg4 12. f3 Bd7 13. Bf2 Nc6 14. Qd2 Ne5 15. b3 e6 16. Nde2 Rc8 17. Bd4 b5 18. Nd1
comment: Notice that white deliberately delayed queenside castling for this manuever.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. Be2 h5 11. Bxg4 Bxg4 12. f3 Bd7 13. Bf2 Nc6 14. Qd2 Ne5 15. b3 e6 16. Nde2 Rc8 17. Bd4 b5 18. Nd1 Rg8 19. Ne3 a5 20. O-O-O a4 21. Kb1 axb3 22. cxb3 Ra8 23. Bc3 Ra6 24. Nc2

1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. Be2 h5 11. Bxg4 Bxg4 12. f3 Bd7 13. Bf2 Nc6 14. Qd2 Ne5 15. b3 e6 16. Nde2 Rc8 17. Bd4 b5 18. Nd1 Rg8 19. Ne3 a5 20. O-O-O a4 21. Kb1 axb3 22. cxb3 Ra8 23. Bc3 Ra6 24. Nc2 Bf8
comment: This one must have really hurt to play, as black's position depends on active pieces to compensate for the structural weaknesses.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. Be2 h5 11. Bxg4 Bxg4 12. f3 Bd7 13. Bf2 Nc6 14. Qd2 Ne5 15. b3 e6 16. Nde2 Rc8 17. Bd4 b5 18. Nd1 Rg8 19. Ne3 a5 20. O-O-O a4 21. Kb1 axb3 22. cxb3 Ra8 23. Bc3 Ra6 24. Nc2 Bf8 25. Nb4 Ra8 26. Nd4 Be7 27. Rhe1 Qc8 28. Bb2 Qb7 29. Ndc2 f6
comment: Finally giving white a fresh complex of pawn weaknesses, which he latches onto within the next few moves.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. Be2 h5 11. Bxg4 Bxg4 12. f3 Bd7 13. Bf2 Nc6 14. Qd2 Ne5 15. b3 e6 16. Nde2 Rc8 17. Bd4 b5 18. Nd1 Rg8 19. Ne3 a5 20. O-O-O a4 21. Kb1 axb3 22. cxb3 Ra8 23. Bc3 Ra6 24. Nc2 Bf8 25. Nb4 Ra8 26. Nd4 Be7 27. Rhe1 Qc8 28. Bb2 Qb7 29. Ndc2 f6 30. Nd4 h4 31. g3 g4 32. f4 Nf3 33. Nxf3 gxf3 34. f5
comment: Excellent.  White grabs control of d5, and completely destroys the potential of black's center pawns.  By the way I like this move for another reason... it fits in with my reaction theory (which is just an expanded version of something Motwani describes in S.T.A.R. Chess) - see the first Rubinstein game I annotated for details.  Basically this is a reaction to 29...f6.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. Be2 h5 11. Bxg4 Bxg4 12. f3 Bd7 13. Bf2 Nc6 14. Qd2 Ne5 15. b3 e6 16. Nde2 Rc8 17. Bd4 b5 18. Nd1 Rg8 19. Ne3 a5 20. O-O-O a4 21. Kb1 axb3 22. cxb3 Ra8 23. Bc3 Ra6 24. Nc2 Bf8 25. Nb4 Ra8 26. Nd4 Be7 27. Rhe1 Qc8 28. Bb2 Qb7 29. Ndc2 f6 30. Nd4 h4 31. g3 g4 32. f4 Nf3 33. Nxf3 gxf3 34. f5 hxg3 35. hxg3 Rxg3 36. Qh2 Rg5 37. Bc1 Rg7 38. Qh5+ Rf7 39. Qxf3
comment: Black resigned. 39... Bf8, while objectively toughest, would have been very dismal, while 39... exf5 goes down in flames. Normally, one would play either line out, but this just wasn't Kasparov's day.
